stance_1: Getting protein is easier with meat
justification: The belief that getting protein is easier with meat directly supports the belief that meat is essential.

stance_1: Getting protein is easier with meat
justification: Feeling weak without meat is explicitly justified by the perceived ease of getting protein from meat.

stance_1: Getting protein is easier with meat
stance_2: I eat every type of meat
justification: Eating every type of meat is plausibly supported by the belief that meat is the easiest source of protein.

stance_1: Getting protein is easier with meat
justification: Enjoyment of meat may be supported by the belief that it provides easy protein, but this is only implicit.

stance_1: Getting protein is easier with meat
stance_2: I am open to trying new meats
justification: Being open to new meats may be supported by the idea that all meat is a good protein source, though the link is weak and implicit.

stance_1: I eat every type of meat
stance_2: I am open to trying new meats
justification: Explicitly, the interviewee states both that they eat all types of meat and are open to trying more, showing strong support.

stance_1: I eat every type of meat
justification: Enjoyment of meat supports the behavior of eating every type of meat.

stance_1: I eat every type of meat
justification: The belief that meat is essential supports the behavior of eating every type of meat.

stance_1: I eat every type of meat
justification: Feeling weak without meat supports the habitual consumption of all meat types.

stance_1: I am open to trying new meats
justification: Enjoyment of meat explicitly supports openness to trying new meats.

stance_1: I am open to trying new meats
justification: If meat is considered essential, being open to new meats is plausibly supported, though not directly stated.

stance_1: I am open to trying new meats
justification: Feeling weak without meat may support trying new meats, though the evidence is thin.
Enjoyment of meat is supported by the belief that it is essential, though this is implicit.
Feeling weak without meat may make eating meat more enjoyable, though the link is implicit.
The belief that meat is essential is explicitly tied to feeling weak without it.
